pros: Not too taxing. Good people. Purposeful work

pros: There is the possibility for a lot of progression .
cons:
Mainly a female majority workplace, females favoured. Highly sexist toward males. Women run the joint and as such everybody is at the mercy of white female managers and other white male managers. Most work force travel from east london and essex and unfairly offer jobs and promotions to their relatives or ethnic counterparts for example in a certain department there are all Caribbean managers, Below them asians slogging away like slaves. Above the Black managers are all White managers in the top paying jobs. Heavy heavy institutional racism and sexism. The old CEO was female and the new CEO is female aswell and white aswell. The physiotherpay department consists about 30 students, out of that about 21 are white females, about 6 are white males and about 3 are asian/black males. Again, every department has a lot of favoritism in terms of promotion and sharing of work. White females given the brunt of the good work and the scraps are given to everybody else. Generally, whites are treated best and have the most opportunity or optimistic outlook because of the earlier mentioned reasons. 

Oh, and VERY stressful work environment and overworking people til they are sick and also having a nightmare sickness policy that almost promotes the dismissal of staff for having sicknesses with a very long monitoring period - that leads to even more stress and worry.

I would not recommend this place at all.

pros: I really cannot say what now
cons: As in so many places the staff are not looked after well.

pros: Good NHS Trust to work with
cons: No concerns as far as I am aware

pros: Good, they help you tontt get schei
cons: Bad, no cons at all

pros: Friendly team, excellent standard of care.
cons: Understaffed, staff shortages taking toll on staff

pros: God will give me ability to do it
cons: Be honest in anywhere you work

pros: Familiar environment and a friendly community. Most of the staff is kind and hard-working.
cons: Management isn’t good. In maternity get promoted based on friendships and culture. I can tell there are 2 ou 3 managers who aren’t British or Black British. Barely anyone else makes it to band 7 or 8. Also, there are more non-clinical jobs than I can count, of people who never get their hands on when things get tough. They’d rather call a poor community midwife to cover a night shift than a clinical practice facilitator that spent her day at the desk or working from home. When things get tough, they cover each other’s backs. There’s lots of favouritism from people who have been working there for many years. Seniors act like they are untouchable, because they can be rubbish at their job but know that they have been there for too long for anyone to tell them anything. I’m glad I have a good majority of the team as friends who understand the struggle.

job_title: Early Years Practitioner in Ilford, England
pros: very good people and working atmosphere
cons: Limited promotion to top leadership for BAME community

review_title: Its very nice place to work in, I really enjoyed my time there.
pros: There is quite an impressive support network, and a very nice environment to work in. Where your opinion and ideas are welcome and appreciated.
cons: It will be nice to be flexible with working times

pros: Friendly work atmosphere. Compact lab setup
cons:
More of paperwork than real patient's work
Demanding for speed against quality

job_title: Associate Workforce Director in London, England
pros: A locally based organisation that cares for its patients and staff delivering innovative healthcare in a challenging inner city public sector environment.
cons: All public funded services are extremely pressured environments within which to work, however, the Homerton as evidenced by ratings from its regulator - CQC and its own staff - National Staff survey, does well despite this.

pros: I have worked at Homerton for 6 years. I waited a long time, about 8 months to get here because of time to do the then CRB check. Matron Jasmine Smith kept in touch with me throughout this time, with words od advice and encouragement. Homerton is like one big happy family and the support I have received  from them throughout my employment has been simply outstanding.
cons: The only thing I can think of is the very high London rents, which is not really their fault.

job_title: Delivery Suite Coordinator in London, England
pros: Staff are respected and valued  - very team orientated.    The client / patient is at the centre of all care planning - staff actively encouraged to remember this and report any concerns to managers
cons: Maternity unit often overstretched  - not enough beds - emphasis put on discharging women before they are ready to leave

pros: Position of influence.  Earn an above-average salary. Chance to change lives. Real staying power. Help develop the people around you.The industry is experiencing steady growth. You feel gratification from solving problems.  Get to welcome rookies.  Each workday is different.  Work with people from different orientations.
cons: If you work about 1/2 hour away from work - train strikes disputes etc.

pros:
Opportunity to work with a wonderful team of Physiotherapists
Opportunity to work in numerous physiotherapy roles both inpatient and outpatient
Opportunity to work in the community
Great for learning and development opportunities
cons: Some areas where there are challenging individuals living in the community

job_title: Community Staff Nurse in Hackney, England
pros: a lot of training available
cons: Difficult to develop professionally, very heavy workload, managers are more concern with meeting targets than the quality of patient care

pros: Staff work their hardest to look after patients with compassion.
cons: Sometimes A&E is busy with long waits but the staff are always working their hardest to see everyone as soon as possible and as safely as possible

job_title: Head of Resourcing in Hackney, England
pros: Homerton is a great place to work.  The working environment is friendly and supportive, and you feel like you can make a real difference to the lives of residents in Hackney and beyond, whatever your role.
cons: I can't think of any.

job_title: Medical Laboratory Assistant in London, England
pros: Busy work and keeps you occupied. Always something to do.
cons: Low pay. Gossip hub. Boring work. Lack of development even with a degree in relevant to the department. Dirty smelly work without appreciation.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in London, England
pros: Good rotational position, supportive team, supervision opportunities, opportunity to get dysphagia competencies / video fluoroscopy competencies
cons: Can feel less prioritised than physio and OT colleagues when it comes to investment in new resources, no paid CPD for band 5s.

pros: So warm and friendly, worked for other hospitals and the staff is no where near as nice at the other hospitals - feel so at home at Homerton.
cons: Area can sometimes be difficult to get to / from at night

job_title: Psychological Wellbeing Practitioner in Hoxton, England
pros:

Friendly colleagues 
Inner London weighting
cons:
Unfair management practices
Very high caseload 
Required to work two late evenings
High wait lists
No room availability
Little progression
